entry.summary: The discussion revolves around the Lightning Network, which is a protocol designed to enable instant, high-volume transactions. This approach involves sending transactions through off-chain channels between parties before settling them on the blockchain. The conversation explores various challenges associated with this approach, including routing payments through different nodes and potential collusion among nodes. One potential solution proposed is introducing reputation as part of the routing service and implementing per-hop max delays for transactions.The discussion also focuses on the implementation of Lightning Network payments and their security. The proposed scheme involves a direct communication link between payer and payee, where they coordinate payment by exchanging information such as the hash of R, to-be-paid amount, and address of the meeting point. It is suggested that payment-by-lightning can be added to other protocols by sharing lists of hashes and preimages. Rusty Russell's latest scheme involves returning a valid unilateral close transaction and using it to prevent upstream from closing.Furthermore, fines can be enforced if a recipient does not respond in time to complete a transaction. It is suggested that fines can be paid from the payee side of a single link to the payer-side of the link if the R value is delayed, and well-behaving nodes will always pay the fine, thereby keeping their link intact and maintaining a healthy network of well-behaving nodes. However, there may be issues when a misbehaving node is at the end of a chain who does not pay their fine but well-behaved nodes make up the rest of the chain.The conversation also considers the possibility of locking in fees cryptographically by updating the channel once an hour with the fees applied to the balances. The idea is that accepting the update would be cheaper than paying a 0.1mBTC blockchain txn fee, as long as less than 10 BTC worth of active transactions are being paid fines on. Overall, the conversation highlights both the promise and complexity of the Lightning Network. While it offers faster and cheaper transactions than relying solely on the blockchain, there are various challenges associated with this approach that must be addressed.
